visuals.title: Like!
visuals.description:
It may take a minute to load from all the resources it's loading.

This sketch works specifically for OpenProcessing.
It searches through the DOM to collect all users who liked this sketch and displays them.

Controls:
- Like this sketch then press f5 to refresh the *page* (not just the sketch). You will then show up here!

UPDATE:
With so many urls to go through, the sketch was taking a very long time to load. After adding a callback, it should now load fast!

Also added numbers beside each name to represent the order when it was liked.

visuals.title: dance Signature
visuals.description:
Digital Signature created by the transformation path of two randomly generated beziere curves. The text you see at the bottom of the sketch is the seed value for the random generator. Change the seed and see what happens.

Controls:
- TYPE SOMETHING = create seed
- MOUSECLICK = create random seed and generate signature
- BACKSPACE/DEL = delete last letter
- RETURN/ENTER/CTRL = confirm your seed and generate signature
- ALT = save image

visuals.title: Camera motion
visuals.description:
Detect motion in a live webcam image using pjs. please keep in mind that i'm using hacks to get  pjs to work with the webcam data. your mileage may vary. Code is an unholy marriage between plain JS, HTML5 objects and PJS, so it will not function in the Processing IDE.
WARNING, COULD BE SLOW!!! (also, WebKit browsers only!)
visuals.instructions: Open in a Webkit browser like Chrome / Safari. Turn your webcam on. Wave your hand, turn your head

visuals.title: Shader
visuals.description:
Creates a fantasy image from your webcam's input using a custom shader.
Example found at https://p5js.org/examples/3d-shader-using-webcam.html
The two shader files had to be renamed, since OpenProcessing would not upload them as 'webcam.vert' and 'webcam.frag'. I renamed them as text files and then they uploaded and worked fine! - Richard Bourne
visuals.instructions: Tap the mouse or screen to save the full screen on a new tab. It will be upside down. Press and hold on the image to get the popup menu and select Save Image. Then in Photos, choose Edit and rotate the image right way up.

visuals.title: polar.Coordinates
visuals.description:
In mathematics, the polar coordinate system is a two-dimensional coordinate system in which each point on a plane is determined by a distance from a reference point and an angle from a reference direction.
The reference point (analogous to the origin of a Cartesian system) is called the pole, and the ray from the pole in the reference direction is the polar axis. The distance from the pole is called the radial coordinate or radius, and the angle is called the angular coordinate, polar angle, or azimuth.

(Wikipedia)

visuals.title: Project_Wallison
visuals.description: This program displays the change in moon phases during a complete cycle. As the moon orbits, we see a different illumination of the moon depending on what is covering it from our view. As shown in the program, there are 8 moon cycles over approximately 29.5 days : The new moon, waxing crescent, first quarter, waxing gibbous, full moon, waning gibbous, last quarter, waning crescent and finally back to a new moon.
visuals.instructions: Depending on which word your mouse cursor is on, the sky will show you a different moon phase. Press the up key to change the font of the opening yellow title as it travels by. Press any other key to change it back! Click the mouse to feel the sun's rays! Click the right arrow key to make blue dots, like mini earths on the canvas, hold down until you want them to go away! Only works one time so decide when you want them to appear. If you want to make the earths appear again simply restart the code! HAVE FUN AND ENJOY THE MOON PHASES!

visuals.title: Project_Walsh
visuals.description: the moon's phases are caused by the revolution of the moon and it's rotation around Earth being the exact same length of 29.53 days. The moon's light comes from the sun's light reflecting off of the moon which can be seen on Earth.  On Earth we always see a different fraction of that light from different angles, which we call phases.
visuals.instructions: move your mouse along the screen to see the different phases of the moon, press and hold the "up arrow" key to see the title slide. press and hold the "down arrow" key to see real images of the moon's phases. (it may take time to load)

visuals.title: Project_Hoffman
visuals.description: A solar eclipse occurs because when the moon orbits, it passes in between the earth and sun. When the moon covers the sun completely, it is called a total eclipse. When the moon only covers part of the sun, it is called a partial eclipse. It is very bad for someone to look directly at a solar eclipse with no eclipse glasses. This is because the sun’s UV lights can seriously damage your eyes.
visuals.instructions:
First, move your mouse off of the canvas. Then
move your mouse to the top of the canvas,
move your mouse to the bottom of the canvas, move your mouse over the sun, and while on the default screen, press and hold any key, and press and hold your mouse.

visuals.title: Kinect 3D scanner
visuals.description:
Simple 3D scanner using the Kinect.

Doesn't work in the browser. You need a Kinect to run it and the controlP5 (version controlP5_1.5.1), hemesh and simple-openni libraries installed. 
 
Select the scanner area with the controls and press the "take scan" button to capture the 3D points inside the box. A mesh is created with the Hemesh library and saved in the sketch directory. The colors of the mesh faces are saved in a different file. Press the "take scan" button again to take more scans. 
 
Use http://www.openprocessing.org/sketch/62533 to read and represent the mesh.

visuals.title: Camera Motion
visuals.description:
Detect motion in a live webcam image using pjs, insert particles into a particle system where motion is detected. 
please keep in mind that i'm using hacks to get  pjs to work with the webcam data. your mileage may vary. Code is an unholy marriage between plain JS, HTML5 objects and PJS, so it will not function in the Processing IDE.

this version features several small improvements ; less looping in render method, maximum number of particles, particles follow direction of motion.
visuals.instructions: Open in a browser like Chrome / Safari / Firefox. Turn your webcam on. Wave your hand, turn your head

visuals.title: Network Builder
visuals.description: Place some nodes and connect them with lines. Then click play to see the physics in action.
visuals.instructions:
Left click to create a new node.
Right click to delete a node.
Left click on one node, then left click on another node to connect them with a line.
Drag a node to move it, even during playback!
Select the square button to create fixed nodes.
Select the circle button to create free-moving nodes.
Click the play button to toggle the physical simulation.

visuals.title: Circulate
visuals.description: Controls: Mouse pressed stops the lines from spiraling inward, and stops showing their paths. Mouse not pressed sends the lines spiraling inward. At first let the mouse hold still in the center for a few seconds, then start. Also try holding down the mouse and moving it around the screen a bit, and then releasing the mouse and hold it perfectly still, watching what happens. The code is relatively easy to figure out, it's a particle system. Enjoy.

visuals.title: Circulate
visuals.description: Controls: Mouse pressed stops the lines from spiraling inward, and stops showing their paths. Mouse not pressed sends the lines spiraling inward. At first let the mouse hold still in the center for a few seconds, then start. Also try holding down the mouse and moving it around the screen a bit, and then releasing the mouse and hold it perfectly still, watching what happens. The code is relatively easy to figure out, it's a particle system. Enjoy.

visuals.title: Rekursion Flower
visuals.description:
Experiment with recursion. Code could be much easier. It got a little messy because I wanted to do something quite different in the beginning (and I did't clean up).

Controls:
Click on the image to get a new flower (position of the mouse affects look of the flower)
+ / - = more / less branches
n = new flower ( + mouse position changes look)
t = toggle flower mode

Flickr set:
http://www.flickr.com/photos/dianalange/sets/72157628815886507/

visuals.title: Typehover
visuals.description: The FitnessGram Pacer Test is a multistage aerobic capacity test that progressively gets more difficult as it continues. The 20 meter pacer test will begin in 30 seconds. Line up at the start. The running speed starts slowly but gets faster each minute after you hear this signal bodeboop. A sing lap should be completed every time you hear this sound. ding Remember to run in a straight line and run as long as possible. The second time you fail to complete a lap before the sound, your test is over. The test will begin on the word start. On your mark. Get ready!… Start.

visuals.title: Art gallery painter
visuals.description:
Maps the image's brightness to determine the stroke's direction and the color's hue.

Mouse click to switch to the next image.

You can try your own image by editing the variable imgNames and the preload on line 1. Images that don't exceed 700px work best. It doesn't capture details well so close ups also work best.
visuals.instructions: Mouse click to switch to the next image.

visuals.title: Vote!

And no, you can't spam your vote!

visuals.title: Lindenmayer Plants
visuals.description:
Finally had some time to extend my old l-system project. Check tutorial for general explanations: http://paulbourke.net/fractals/lsys/. This time most replacement rules consist of sets of possible replacements which are chosen randomly within a given likelihood. The axiom and the replacements (with their likelihoods) are written on the bottom of the drawing:

Controls:
Click with mouse = new random plant
Space = same plant with new random values
Left/ Right Arrow = increase / decrease angle
Plus / Minus = add / remove  iteration (don't add too much iterations)
t = show / hide text

visuals.title: Catch That Arial

Arial and Helvetica are two typefaces that you cannot escape from in this modern life. If you pay (maybe just a little bit) attention to fonts, I guess this has occurs to you: Is that text in Arial or Helvetica? 

Read the stories between these two typefaces here: 

Indeed, they are very similar but still there are some clues to find. Click ↓and try to catch the Arial among the Helvetica-s!

visuals.title: Rorschach Generator
visuals.description:
To see how this works, hit 'f' to disable the filter. You'll see that the balls are darkest at the center and lightest at the outside. The filter gets rid of everything lighter than the threshold, and turns everything else black. 


controls:
Various modes of motion: 1-7
Reset everything: z
Toggle Rorschach mode: r
Cycle through shapes: s
Invert shape: i
Invert colors toggle: b
Random/BW color switch: c
Pause motion: p
Filter toggle: f
Discrete/Continuous: d

Change number of balls: _,+
Change radius: -,=
Change discretization steps: {,}
Adjust threshold: [,]

visuals.title: Noise flow field painter
visuals.description:
*It may need a moment to load*

Paints an image with strokes that are rotated by a flow field driven from noise.

If you want to try it on your own image you need to drag and drop an image in the sketch's files tab. Then add your image's file name to the variable imgNames (it's near the top). It doesn't capture details very well so close ups work best.

Controls:
  - Click to change to the next image.
  - Press any key to save the canvas to a jpg.
visuals.instructions: Click for the next image, press a key to save a jpg.

visuals.title: Tangram
visuals.description:
A simple tangram game
Hover over the black square in the top left corner. White activation circles occure. If you click on one of the circles the corresponding tangram shape is activated. You then can move it to another position and rotate it by 45 degrees by pressing the space bar. An other click deactivates it. Press 'c' to reset all shapes to their original position in the top left corner. Press 'b' to rotate the shape counterclockwise by 5 degrees. Press 'n' to reset the rotation to 0 degrees. Press 'm' to rotate the shape clockwise by 5 degrees. Press 'l' to toggle lines.

visuals.title: Image based triangulation
visuals.description:
Drawing machine based on http://www.openprocessing.org/sketch/81905

Uses Lee Byron's Mesh Library:
http://www.leebyron.com/else/mesh/

Little bit slow because the triangulation has to be calculated every frame.

Controls:
Left mouse button = restart
Right mouse button = restart /w full resolution
1 / 2 / 3 = choose image
M = change movement mode
B = transparent background on / off
I = show / hide current input image
R = random image on / off

(Work in progress) Video:
https://vimeo.com/54590461

visuals.title: text011
visuals.description:
Digital Signature created by the transformation path of two randomly generated beziere curves. The text you see at the bottom of the sketch is the seed value for the random generator. Change the seed and see what happens.

Controls:
- TYPE SOMETHING = create seed
- MOUSECLICK = create random seed and generate signature
- BACKSPACE/DEL = delete last letter
- RETURN/ENTER/CTRL = confirm your seed and generate signature
- ALT = save image

visuals.title: Catch That Arial
visuals.description:
Arial and Helvetica are two typefaces that you cannot escape from in this modern life. If you pay (maybe just a little bit) attention to fonts, I guess this has occurs to you: Is that text in Arial or Helvetica? 

Read the stories between these two typefaces here: 

Indeed, they are very similar but still there are some clues to find. Click ↓and try to catch the Arial among the Helvetica-s!

visuals.description: 迷路ゲームを作りました。キーボードの矢印キーで赤いボールを操作します。最初から最後まで苦戦して、迷路の道が表示されなかったりボールが動かなかったりしましたが、一番苦労した点は、ボールが線に当たった時の設定です。残念ながら簡潔なコードにはできなかったのですが、オリジナルの迷路でゲームとしては機能させることができました。壁に当たったらやり直しです。Can you reach the GOAL? Let's try!

visuals.title: Image based triangulation
visuals.description:
Drawing machine based on http://www.openprocessing.org/sketch/81905

Uses Lee Byron's Mesh Library:
http://www.leebyron.com/else/mesh/

Little bit slow because the triangulation has to be calculated every frame.

Controls:
Left mouse button = restart
Right mouse button = restart /w full resolution
1 / 2 / 3 = choose image
M = change movement mode
B = transparent background on / off
I = show / hide current input image
R = random image on / off

(Work in progress) Video:
https://vimeo.com/54590461

visuals.title: Circulate
visuals.description: Controls: Mouse pressed stops the lines from spiraling inward, and stops showing their paths. Mouse not pressed sends the lines spiraling inward. At first let the mouse hold still in the center for a few seconds, then start. Also try holding down the mouse and moving it around the screen a bit, and then releasing the mouse and hold it perfectly still, watching what happens. The code is relatively easy to figure out, it's a particle system. Enjoy.

visuals.title: Image based triangulation
visuals.description:
Drawing machine based on http://www.openprocessing.org/sketch/81905

Uses Lee Byron's Mesh Library:
http://www.leebyron.com/else/mesh/

Little bit slow because the triangulation has to be calculated every frame.

Controls:
Left mouse button = restart
Right mouse button = restart /w full resolution
1 / 2 / 3 = choose image
M = change movement mode
B = transparent background on / off
I = show / hide current input image
R = random image on / off

(Work in progress) Video:
https://vimeo.com/54590461

visuals.title: Recursive Tree
visuals.description:
Since everybody got one: Here is my version of a recursive Tree. The text you see at the bottom of the sketch is the seed value for the random generator. Change the seed and see what happens.

Controls:
- TYPE SOMETHING = create seed
- MOUSECLICK = create random seed and generate tree
- BACKSPACE/DEL = delete last letter
- RETURN/ENTER/CTRL = confirm your seed and generate tree
- ALT = save image

visuals.title: Feather
visuals.description:
I think it looks better on java mode, we can see the intersection of the barbs.
On javaScript mode it's too smooth, it seems that the barbs with the same direction form one solid thing.
Still, I really like this sketch.
visuals.instructions: Click to generate a new colorful feather.

visuals.title: Twk: Feather
visuals.description: Excellent job by Bárbara Almeida! I just got rid of the colors.

visuals.title: rescued from oblivion: Feathers
visuals.description:
openprocessing.org has thousands of sketches that have been marked "Archived Sketch: This sketch is created  with an older version of Processing, and doesn't work on browsers anymore." Most of them work fine, or do so after editing a single line. Some of them - like this one - deserve to be rescued from oblivion.

Original description:

Generates random feathers based on user's mouse click. Feathers created closer to the left are more organized "flight" feathers, whereas feathers created on the right side are more disorganized "downy" feathers.

visuals.title: Feather
visuals.description:
I think it looks better on java mode, we can see the intersection of the barbs.
On javaScript mode it's too smooth, it seems that the barbs with the same direction form one solid thing.
Still, I really like this sketch.
visuals.instructions: Click to generate a new colorful feather. You will get a new tab with a saveable image. Delete it if you don't want it.

The triangulation is still very slow in JS, some customization could be used ;-) Run locally to increase the sketch size and the number of points.

visuals.title: Delaunay Subdivision
visuals.description:
(unoptimized) Delaunay triangulation with various display modes.
The graphic starts with two triangles. Each frame new triangles are added. The new triangles are made from a subdivision of one existing triangle - one triangle is subdivided into three new triangles. The triangle who gets subdivided is choosen at random.  Delaunay triangulation implementation done from scratch. See code for references.
visuals.instructions: Press mouse to switch between display modes. Press any key for new graphic.

visuals.title: Islamic Stars
visuals.description:
Move the mouse horizontally and vertically to change the image.  X and Y control two different parameters.

This was an experiment with a method used to produce Arabic/Islamic star tiling patterns, from an underlying grid of polygons.

Starting with an underlying grid of polygons, the star pattern is produced by drawing lines from two equidistant points on each polygon edge at some fixed angle (controlled by the mouse).  At the point where the lines would intersect with other lines, they are clipped.

Y controls the distance from the center of the polygon edge.
X controls angle.

visuals.title: EEG-FLOW
visuals.description:
We see the envelope of multiple oscillations from the human resting state EEG during eyes closed. A chunk of 20 sec is plotted clockwise circularly along the outer edge The time series shrinks, changes color and slowly starts to oscillate tangentially as it gets attracted towards the center of the circle, leaving behind multiple traces of itself. A pulsating, hypnotic figure emerges, reminiscent of a sea urchin or a flower

Move mouse towards right-left edge to shrink-grow shape.
move mouse vertically to increase the amplitude of the oscillation of the tangential rotation.
Click to reset

visuals.title: Biomorpha Europensis
visuals.description: Biomorphs are strange and eerily biological-looking complex number fractal forms of startling variety. The simplest look like primitive monocellular blobs with infinitely descending internal contours, some of which openly betray their algorithmic relation to the Fatou-Julia sets through their dragon-like spirals. While others display remarkably complex structures ranging from microbiological-looking forms reminiscent of Hooke's radiolaria to exotic floral shapes: inveritable microbes from the complex plane.
visuals.instructions: Click to toggle interactive mode, where the mouse cursor's position defines the biomorph's seed.

visuals.title: Rorschach Generator
visuals.description:
To see how this works, hit 'f' to disable the filter. You'll see that the balls are darkest at the center and lightest at the outside. The filter gets rid of everything lighter than the threshold, and turns everything else black. 


controls:
Various modes of motion: 1-7
Reset everything: z
Toggle Rorschach mode: r
Cycle through shapes: s
Invert shape: i
Invert colors toggle: b
Random/BW color switch: c
Pause motion: p
Filter toggle: f
Discrete/Continuous: d

Change number of balls: _,+
Change radius: -,=
Change discretization steps: {,}
Adjust threshold: [,]

Just playing with noise.

* I've used a different strategy to make the color transitions smooth

* I've used the equation of the torus to make the pattern seamless

visuals.title: Biomorpha Europensis
visuals.description: Biomorphs are strange and eerily biological-looking complex number fractal forms of startling variety. The simplest look like primitive monocellular blobs with infinitely descending internal contours, some of which openly betray their algorithmic relation to the Fatou-Julia sets through their dragon-like spirals. While others display remarkably complex structures ranging from microbiological-looking forms reminiscent of Hooke's radiolaria to exotic floral shapes: inveritable microbes from the complex plane.
visuals.instructions: Click to toggle interactive mode, where the mouse cursor's position defines the biomorph's seed.

visuals.title: Ideal Triangles in the Poincaré disc
visuals.description:
When using the Poincaré disc model for hyperbolic geometry, the hyperbolic universe is inside a circle. The circle itself is at infinity. A triangle inside the circle will always have angle sum < 180 degrees. As the vertices of a triangle approach the circle, the angle sum tends to 0, and the hyperbolic perimeter tends to infinity. The limiting triangle is called an ideal triangle. The hyperbolic area of an ideal triangle is always pi. All triangles in the animation have the same hyperbolic area. 

The animation is used on http://www.malinc.se/math/noneuclidean/mainen.php

Press 'd' to hide/show the red dots. 

Used on http://www.malinc.se/math/geometry/apolloniangasketen.php

visuals.title: Making a Bézier Spline

visuals.title: Continuity of Bézier splines
visuals.description:
Move the points to make the green curve continuous! 
Move the points to make the blue curve continuous! (you probably ruin the continuity of the green curve)
Hide the velocity and acceleration vectors and show the mirror points! 
When C2 lies on the grey mirror point C1', the velocity is continuous. 
When the yellow mirror points C0' and C3' coincide, the acceleration is continuous. 
Lock C2 and C3 to an A-shape! Move the other points!

visuals.title: The flatness of Bézier curves

visuals.title: Splitting a Bézier Curve
visuals.description:
When drawing a Bézier curve recursively, the curve is split into two new Bézier curves. The recursion ends when the Bézier curve is "flat enough.

Split and combine!  Move the red points.

visuals.title: de Casteljau's algorithm

visuals.title: Fluid Simulation + Momentum Transfer + Electrostatic Force
visuals.description:
Mouse-interactive fluid simulation with particles.
The fluid simulation is solved on a 16x16 cell grid.
Using Verlet integration for the particle update.
Every particle has an electric charge and two of them have a static value. When any two  particles collide, they equally share it. The border is the electric ground. There's a nonlinear friction and on every collision there's a tiny amount of 1% energy lost, so its passive state approaches a global lower limit energy.
So far, the binding of the forces is one-way only and the particle motion doesn't add to the fluid simulation.
Have fun!

visuals.title: Ideal Triangles in the Poincaré disc
visuals.description:
When using the Poincaré disc model for hyperbolic geometry, the hyperbolic universe is inside a circle. The circle itself is at infinity. A triangle inside the circle will always have angle sum < 180 degrees. As the vertices of a triangle approach the circle, the angle sum tends to 0, and the hyperbolic perimeter tends to infinity. The limiting triangle is called an ideal triangle. The hyperbolic area of an ideal triangle is always pi. All triangles in the animation have the same hyperbolic area. 

The animation is used on http://www.malinc.se/math/noneuclidean/mainen.php

visuals.title: Poincare Hyperbolic Disk Tiling
visuals.description: This sketch illustrates an algorithm for drawing checkered patterns on the the Poincare disk. The Poincare disk is a model of hyperbolic geometry. The pattern is defined by reflections in the circles shown. For each point we check weather it is inside any of the circles. If not, it must be in that triangular space in the middle,  the only bit thats not inside any of the circles. So we draw that pixel white. Otherwise we repeatedly “reflect” the point until it finds its way to the middle triangle. We then colour it depending on weather it took an even or odd number of reflections.
visuals.instructions: Click on any point to see its orbit to the centre under multiple reflections.

visuals.title: Dynamic Background School of Fish
visuals.description:
This is based on Akiyoshi Kitaoka's School of Fish illusion: http://www.psy.ritsumei.ac.jp/~akitaoka/movinschooloffish01.jpg

You can modulate the luminance of the background with the Y position of the mouse, and invert the luminance by clicking. Position the mouse near the top or bottom of the screen and click repeatedly to induce strong transient motion. It seems that adjusting the luminance within the range which exists within the fish themselves gives the strongest effect.

visuals.title: Optical Illusion #5 (Hering Illusion)
visuals.description:
The red lines are straight but appear to be bent.

Explanation by livescience.com:
"Evolution has seen to it that geometric drawings like this elicit in us premonitions of the near future. The converging lines toward a vanishing point (the spokes) are cues that trick our brains into thinking we are moving forward as we would in the real world, where the door frame (a pair of vertical lines) seems to bow out as we move through it and we try to perceive what that world will look like in the next instant."

visuals.title: 100 Boxes Zooming
visuals.description:
A 10x10 grid of 100 squares zooming out. Pressing a mouse button freezes the animation; releasing it starts it over.

A little optical illusion: Stare at the grid while it shrinks, then when it gets down to about a third of the window's size, freeze it with the mouse button. It will appear to grow briefly, but it really is frozen.

visuals.title: Práctica 4, olas
visuals.description: Ejercicio de la práctica 4, correspondiente a la simulación en 3D de un objeto deformable basado en ondas, concretamente olas de tres tipos. Con la tecla W se generan olas simples/direccionales, con R olas radiales y con G olas Gerstner. También se pueden crear olas radiales con el ratón. Con la tecla C se activa/desactiva la visualización de la cuadrícula de su malla. Con la tecla T se activa/desactiva la textura. Con la barra espaciadora se vuelve al mar en calma. Debido a un bug de Processing.js, la iluminación no es correcta. Vídeo: https://youtu.be/qfwevzzHvo8

visuals.title: Lindenmayer Plants
visuals.description:
Finally had some time to extend my old l-system project. Check tutorial for general explanations: http://paulbourke.net/fractals/lsys/. This time most replacement rules consist of sets of possible replacements which are chosen randomly within a given likelihood. The axiom and the replacements (with their likelihoods) are written on the bottom of the drawing:

Controls:
Click with mouse = new random plant
Space = same plant with new random values
Left/ Right Arrow = increase / decrease angle
Plus / Minus = add / remove  iteration (don't add too much iterations)
t = show / hide text

visuals.title: Action Poem
visuals.description: We write visual poetry. This proposal is an interactive and performative poem that could be text and image in parallel. We work with lines of code to connect poetry (such as language and human process) with code (such as language and electronic process), images are then the manifestation (result) of this process, and a form of translation.

visuals.title: Circular Network 2
visuals.description:
The program reads in .txt files and sorts nodes according to their sizes. The largest node is at 12'o clock position and the sizes decrease clockwise.

Color can represent another dimension of information, right now they represent the same information as size does. 

Red nodes always have their names displayed and other nodes display their names if you place your mouse over them.

You can adjust the THRESHOLD variable to display more edges. Most of the edges are 100% transparent now.

Thanks and enjoy! I will add some comments to my codes when I have time.

visuals.title: Oil-water phase separation
visuals.description:
A 2D model of how oil and water molecules repel each other with different strengths, making them self-assemble into groups. Based on the PhD thesis of Naoaki Ono.

The mouse controls a water molecule so you can push the oil blobs around.

If you want to play it as a game, try this:

Task 1: push all the blobs together into one big blob.

Task 2: split the big blob into little blobs. You get more points for the more separate blobs you make.

(Note: there aren't any points, you will have to make up your own scoring system.)
visuals.instructions: Move the mouse to push the oil blobs around

visuals.title: Rorschach Generator
visuals.description:
To see how this works, hit 'f' to disable the filter. You'll see that the balls are darkest at the center and lightest at the outside. The filter gets rid of everything lighter than the threshold, and turns everything else black. 


controls:
Various modes of motion: 1-7
Reset everything: z
Toggle Rorschach mode: r
Cycle through shapes: s
Invert shape: i
Invert colors toggle: b
Random/BW color switch: c
Pause motion: p
Filter toggle: f
Discrete/Continuous: d

Change number of balls: _,+
Change radius: -,=
Change discretization steps: {,}
Adjust threshold: [,]

visuals.title: rescued from oblivion: Feathers
visuals.description:
openprocessing.org has thousands of sketches that have been marked "Archived Sketch: This sketch is created  with an older version of Processing, and doesn't work on browsers anymore." Most of them work fine, or do so after editing a single line. Some of them - like this one - deserve to be rescued from oblivion.

Original description:

Generates random feathers based on user's mouse click. Feathers created closer to the left are more organized "flight" feathers, whereas feathers created on the right side are more disorganized "downy" feathers.

visuals.title: Delaunay Subdivision
visuals.description:
(unoptimized) Delaunay triangulation with various display modes.
The graphic starts with two triangles. Each frame new triangles are added. The new triangles are made from a subdivision of one existing triangle - one triangle is subdivided into three new triangles. The triangle who gets subdivided is choosen at random.  Delaunay triangulation implementation done from scratch. See code for references.
visuals.instructions: Press mouse to switch between display modes. Press any key for new graphic.

visuals.title: Islamic Stars
visuals.description:
Move the mouse horizontally and vertically to change the image.  X and Y control two different parameters.

This was an experiment with a method used to produce Arabic/Islamic star tiling patterns, from an underlying grid of polygons.

Starting with an underlying grid of polygons, the star pattern is produced by drawing lines from two equidistant points on each polygon edge at some fixed angle (controlled by the mouse).  At the point where the lines would intersect with other lines, they are clipped.

Y controls the distance from the center of the polygon edge.
X controls angle.

visuals.title: EEG-FLOW
visuals.description:
We see the envelope of multiple oscillations from the human resting state EEG during eyes closed. A chunk of 20 sec is plotted clockwise circularly along the outer edge The time series shrinks, changes color and slowly starts to oscillate tangentially as it gets attracted towards the center of the circle, leaving behind multiple traces of itself. A pulsating, hypnotic figure emerges, reminiscent of a sea urchin or a flower

Move mouse towards right-left edge to shrink-grow shape.
move mouse vertically to increase the amplitude of the oscillation of the tangential rotation.
Click to reset

visuals.title: Biomorpha Europensis
visuals.description: Biomorphs are strange and eerily biological-looking complex number fractal forms of startling variety. The simplest look like primitive monocellular blobs with infinitely descending internal contours, some of which openly betray their algorithmic relation to the Fatou-Julia sets through their dragon-like spirals. While others display remarkably complex structures ranging from microbiological-looking forms reminiscent of Hooke's radiolaria to exotic floral shapes: inveritable microbes from the complex plane.
visuals.instructions: Click to toggle interactive mode, where the mouse cursor's position defines the biomorph's seed.

visuals.title: Rorschach Generator
visuals.description:
To see how this works, hit 'f' to disable the filter. You'll see that the balls are darkest at the center and lightest at the outside. The filter gets rid of everything lighter than the threshold, and turns everything else black. 


controls:
Various modes of motion: 1-7
Reset everything: z
Toggle Rorschach mode: r
Cycle through shapes: s
Invert shape: i
Invert colors toggle: b
Random/BW color switch: c
Pause motion: p
Filter toggle: f
Discrete/Continuous: d

Change number of balls: _,+
Change radius: -,=
Change discretization steps: {,}
Adjust threshold: [,]

visuals.title: Psychedelic Noise
visuals.description:
Just playing with noise.

Mouse click to generate a new seamless pattern
Press any key to save it

It is similar to an old sketch of mine (http://www.openprocessing.org/sketch/187650) but with some important differences:

* I've played with noiseDetail this time to make the curves smoother

* I've used a different strategy to make the color transitions smooth

* I've used the equation of the torus to make the pattern seamless

visuals.title: Ideal Triangles in the Poincaré disc
visuals.description:
When using the Poincaré disc model for hyperbolic geometry, the hyperbolic universe is inside a circle. The circle itself is at infinity. A triangle inside the circle will always have angle sum < 180 degrees. As the vertices of a triangle approach the circle, the angle sum tends to 0, and the hyperbolic perimeter tends to infinity. The limiting triangle is called an ideal triangle. The hyperbolic area of an ideal triangle is always pi. All triangles in the animation have the same hyperbolic area. 

The animation is used on http://www.malinc.se/math/noneuclidean/mainen.php

Press 'p' to hide/show the yellow circles perpendicular to the Apollonian circles.
Press 'd' to hide/show the red dots. 

Used on http://www.malinc.se/math/geometry/apolloniangasketen.php

visuals.title: Continuity of Bézier splines
visuals.description:
Move the points to make the green curve continuous! 
Move the points to make the blue curve continuous! (you probably ruin the continuity of the green curve)
Hide the velocity and acceleration vectors and show the mirror points! 
When C2 lies on the grey mirror point C1', the velocity is continuous. 
When the yellow mirror points C0' and C3' coincide, the acceleration is continuous. 
Lock C2 and C3 to an A-shape! Move the other points!

visuals.title: The flatness of Bézier curves

visuals.title: Splitting a Bézier Curve

visuals.title: Fluid Simulation + Momentum Transfer + Electrostatic Force
visuals.description:
Mouse-interactive fluid simulation with particles.
The fluid simulation is solved on a 16x16 cell grid.
Using Verlet integration for the particle update.
Every particle has an electric charge and two of them have a static value. When any two  particles collide, they equally share it. The border is the electric ground. There's a nonlinear friction and on every collision there's a tiny amount of 1% energy lost, so its passive state approaches a global lower limit energy.
So far, the binding of the forces is one-way only and the particle motion doesn't add to the fluid simulation.
Have fun!

visuals.title: Poincare Hyperbolic Disk Tiling
visuals.description: This sketch illustrates an algorithm for drawing checkered patterns on the the Poincare disk. The Poincare disk is a model of hyperbolic geometry. The pattern is defined by reflections in the circles shown. For each point we check weather it is inside any of the circles. If not, it must be in that triangular space in the middle,  the only bit thats not inside any of the circles. So we draw that pixel white. Otherwise we repeatedly “reflect” the point until it finds its way to the middle triangle. We then colour it depending on weather it took an even or odd number of reflections.
visuals.instructions: Click on any point to see its orbit to the centre under multiple reflections.

visuals.title: Ideal Triangles in the Poincaré disc
visuals.description:
When using the Poincaré disc model for hyperbolic geometry, the hyperbolic universe is inside a circle. The circle itself is at infinity. A triangle inside the circle will always have angle sum < 180 degrees. As the vertices of a triangle approach the circle, the angle sum tends to 0, and the hyperbolic perimeter tends to infinity. The limiting triangle is called an ideal triangle. The hyperbolic area of an ideal triangle is always pi. All triangles in the animation have the same hyperbolic area. 

The animation is used on http://www.malinc.se/math/noneuclidean/mainen.php

visuals.title: Dynamic Background School of Fish
visuals.description:
This is based on Akiyoshi Kitaoka's School of Fish illusion: http://www.psy.ritsumei.ac.jp/~akitaoka/movinschooloffish01.jpg

You can modulate the luminance of the background with the Y position of the mouse, and invert the luminance by clicking. Position the mouse near the top or bottom of the screen and click repeatedly to induce strong transient motion. It seems that adjusting the luminance within the range which exists within the fish themselves gives the strongest effect.

visuals.title: Optical Illusion #5 (Hering Illusion)
visuals.description:
The red lines are straight but appear to be bent.

Explanation by livescience.com:
"Evolution has seen to it that geometric drawings like this elicit in us premonitions of the near future. The converging lines toward a vanishing point (the spokes) are cues that trick our brains into thinking we are moving forward as we would in the real world, where the door frame (a pair of vertical lines) seems to bow out as we move through it and we try to perceive what that world will look like in the next instant."

visuals.title: 100 Boxes Zooming

A little optical illusion: Stare at the grid while it shrinks, then when it gets down to about a third of the window's size, freeze it with the mouse button. It will appear to grow briefly, but it really is frozen.

visuals.title: Práctica 4, olas
visuals.description: Ejercicio de la práctica 4, correspondiente a la simulación en 3D de un objeto deformable basado en ondas, concretamente olas de tres tipos. Con la tecla W se generan olas simples/direccionales, con R olas radiales y con G olas Gerstner. También se pueden crear olas radiales con el ratón. Con la tecla C se activa/desactiva la visualización de la cuadrícula de su malla. Con la tecla T se activa/desactiva la textura. Con la barra espaciadora se vuelve al mar en calma. Debido a un bug de Processing.js, la iluminación no es correcta. Vídeo: https://youtu.be/qfwevzzHvo8

visuals.title: Lindenmayer Plants
visuals.description:
Finally had some time to extend my old l-system project. Check tutorial for general explanations: http://paulbourke.net/fractals/lsys/. This time most replacement rules consist of sets of possible replacements which are chosen randomly within a given likelihood. The axiom and the replacements (with their likelihoods) are written on the bottom of the drawing:

Controls:
Click with mouse = new random plant
Space = same plant with new random values
Left/ Right Arrow = increase / decrease angle
Plus / Minus = add / remove  iteration (don't add too much iterations)
t = show / hide text

visuals.description: We write visual poetry. This proposal is an interactive and performative poem that could be text and image in parallel. visuals.title: Circulate
visuals.description: Controls: Mouse pressed stops the lines from spiraling inward, and stops showing their paths. Mouse not pressed sends the lines spiraling inward. At first let the mouse hold still in the center for a few seconds, then start. Also try holding down the mouse and moving it around the screen a bit, and then releasing the mouse and hold it perfectly still, watching what happens. The code is relatively easy to figure out, it's a particle system. Enjoy.

Inspired by lesson 38 of Fun Programming: http://funprogramming.org/38-Animate-the-ocean-surface-using-noise.html 

Colors chosen to work on Javascript (the clouds and the sky gradient look different on Java mode). Also, I don't know why, the lerpColor didn't work on Java, it's possible to get the same effect with separated map functions for hue, saturation and brightness though.

visuals.title: Typehover
visuals.description: The FitnessGram Pacer Test is a multistage aerobic capacity test that progressively gets more difficult as it continues. The 20 meter pacer test will begin in 30 seconds. Line up at the start. The running speed starts slowly but gets faster each minute after you hear this signal bodeboop. A sing lap should be completed every time you hear this sound. ding Remember to run in a straight line and run as long as possible. The second time you fail to complete a lap before the sound, your test is over. The test will begin on the word start. On your mark. Get ready!… Start.

visuals.title: EEG-FLOW
visuals.description:
We see the envelope of multiple oscillations from the human resting state EEG during eyes closed. A chunk of 20 sec is plotted clockwise circularly along the outer edge The time series shrinks, changes color and slowly starts to oscillate tangentially as it gets attracted towards the center of the circle, leaving behind multiple traces of itself. A pulsating, hypnotic figure emerges, reminiscent of a sea urchin or a flower

Move mouse towards right-left edge to shrink-grow shape.
move mouse vertically to increase the amplitude of the oscillation of the tangential rotation.
Click to reset

visuals.title: Word Spiral
visuals.description:
A fork of Word Spiral by Henry.

A sketch I created for my gf's blog (http://www.rawpossibility.com).  Wordpress lets you export all text within your blog so I extracted her data and used it to create this spiral.  It parses the text and arranges the words by frequency; big words on outer edge are more frequent.
It's a bit sloppy and I had issues making this work with Processing.js as  I created it in Java first.  Please forgive the bubble sort and other such things, inefficient but enough to get it on the site so she could post it. - Henry
visuals.instructions:
Press the left and right arrow to select words. Also use the buttons.
Processing commands save() and saveImage() no longer work. Do a frame grab from a fullScreen browser instead.

visuals.title: Like!
visuals.description:
It may take a minute to load from all the resources it's loading.

This sketch works specifically for OpenProcessing.
It searches through the DOM to collect all users who liked this sketch and displays them.

Controls:
- Like this sketch then press f5 to refresh the *page* (not just the sketch). You will then show up here!

UPDATE:
With so many urls to go through, the sketch was taking a very long time to load. After adding a callback, it should now load fast!

Also added numbers beside each name to represent the order when it was liked.

visuals.title: Práctica 4, olas
visuals.description: Ejercicio de la práctica 4, correspondiente a la simulación en 3D de un objeto deformable basado en ondas, concretamente olas de tres tipos. Con la tecla W se generan olas simples/direccionales, con R olas radiales y con G olas Gerstner. También se pueden crear olas radiales con el ratón. Con la tecla C se activa/desactiva la visualización de la cuadrícula de su malla. Con la tecla T se activa/desactiva la textura. Con la barra espaciadora se vuelve al mar en calma. Debido a un bug de Processing.js, la iluminación no es correcta. Vídeo: https://youtu.be/qfwevzzHvo8

visuals.title: Circulate
visuals.description: Controls: Mouse pressed stops the lines from spiraling inward, and stops showing their paths. Mouse not pressed sends the lines spiraling inward. At first let the mouse hold still in the center for a few seconds, then start. The code is relatively easy to figure out, it's a particle system. Enjoy.

visuals.title: Noise flow field painter
visuals.description:
*It may need a moment to load*

Paints an image with strokes that are rotated by a flow field driven from noise.

If you want to try it on your own image you need to drag and drop an image in the sketch's files tab. Then add your image's file name to the variable imgNames (it's near the top). It doesn't capture details very well so close ups work best.

Controls:
  - Click to change to the next image.
  - Press any key to save the canvas to a jpg.
visuals.instructions: Click for the next image, press a key to save a jpg.

Another version can be seen here:

comments.text: This is fun. Just curious, where does the approximation of the major triad as [4,5,6] and major as [10,12,15]  come from?

@laurent aw thanks! these notes might be of interest to you http://www.phy.mtu.edu/~suits/chords.html
this was just going off the ratios between a major and minor chord on an equal tempered scale
I can play with this forever. <3
As a musician and coder, I'm in love with the sound stuff you've included ♥u♥
Cool Indeed. (sorry to ask, but why a copy/paste in my sketch returns the following error : mySketch, Line 42: p5.SinOsc is not a constructor) Thx
@antheor make  sure you're including the p5.sound library :~) there's a lot of awesome stuff in there

Humble question.
what language is this code written in?
great work alex! i've been trying to understand it for the better part of the last hour. haha.

Less is more! Very elegant work, friend! Beautiful! I've forked to correct the audio click that was happening at mouseRelease. This was due to the call to stop() interrupting the ramp to zero volume one line before. Now the oscillators are always playing...
This was written in p5js, which is basically a JavaScript framework.
its not uncomfy i have to show this to the viewers
Has been my favourite sketch for years, had to come back and find it.
